awd_titl_txt: Workshop to Enhance Collaboration Between US and Indonesia in Biodiversity and Conservation Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Beyond the inherent value of life on earth, we all depend on biodiversity for our own well-being. Diverse and healthy ecosystems are the basis of many livelihoods, they provide clean air and water, offer recreational and tourism opportunities, and are a buffer to natural disasters. Biodiversity is also the basis for our food, much of the world?s medicine and many of the products we rely on. With increasing global threats to the survival and health of the world's biota, it is crucial to the environmental and economic health of the world to document, understand, and conserve biodiversity. This workshop aims to engage and prepare US biodiversity researchers for broad international and interdisciplinary collaborations and the development of infrastructure and predictive tools that can help address pressing biodiversity research and conservation needs globally, and in the US.

This workshop will take place in Indonesia, as a region that hosts a disproportionately large amount of global biodiversity. It engages US and Indonesian scientists working across disciplines of biodiversity science to discuss and strategize how to best collaborate in efforts to continue to discover, document, understand, and conserve biodiversity in a way that also considers human needs. Topics of the workshop will include building and managing successful collaborations, data sharing, applying new technologies to basic ecological and evolutionary questions as well as applied conservation issues, and training students and researchers at various career stages in valuable new technologies. The most immediate outcome of the workshop will be a publication identifying common and complementary areas of interests, synthesizing challenges and opportunities and recommending future steps in biodiversity research. The ultimate goal is to establish productive international research partnerships allowing for collaborative and comprehensive study of ecosystems and the biodiversity they encompass in a global context and facilitate international exchange and critical training of students and professionals, ultimately leading to more successful approaches for addressing global problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Beyond the inherent value of life on earth, we all depend on biodiversity for our own well-being. Diverse and healthy ecosystems are the basis of many livelihoods, they provide clean air and water, offer recreational and tourism opportunities, and are a buffer to natural disasters. Biodiversity is also the basis for our food, much of the world’s medicine and many of the products we rely on. With increasing global threats to the survival and health of the world's biota, it is crucial to the environmental and economic health of the world to document, understand, and conserve biodiversity. “The Workshop to Enhance Collaboration Between US and Indonesia in Biodiversity and Conservation Research” aimed to engage and prepare US biodiversity researchers for broad international and interdisciplinary collaborations that can help address pressing biodiversity research and conservation needs globally, and in the US.

The workshop took place in Indonesia, a biodiversity hotspot that hosts a disproportionately large amount of global biodiversity. The funding was used to bring together US-based and Indonesian biodiversity scientists to focus on building research connections and collaborations to help advance understanding of biodiversity and address threats to it. The workshop convened in July 2019 at the Agricultural University Bogor (IPB, Institut Pertanian Bogor) in Bogor, Indonesia. Over 40 Indonesian biodiversity scientists were present, and they were funded by the Indonesian government. The NSF grant funded the participation of 23 US-based scientists (11 female, 12 male), who ranged in their career stages (graduate students through senior scientists), as well as in their research expertise (sciences and humanities), in the organisms they study (e.g. plants, animals, fungi, microbes, marine life, terrestrial life), and in their methodological approaches to biodiversity issues (e.g. genomics, ecology, biochemistry, computer science, ethnography, and more).

After the initial workshop in 2019, plans were made to have a follow-up, in-person meeting in Indonesia in summer 2020. Due to Covid-19 this was initially postponed to summer 2021, and ultimately canceled due to remaining travel restrictions in 2021. Nonetheless, as a result of the initial workshop, several new international research collaborations – focused on understanding and conserving biodiversity – were initiated and continue to develop. Additionally, due to connections made, one of the Indonesian participants was awarded a Fulbright Fellowship to visit the US to further build collaborations in biodiversity research. Overall, the workshop allowed for scientists at various career stages, including graduate students, to forge new international collaborations to advance research, build a better understanding and context for biodiversity and conservation research work (including logistical considerations and navigating the changing policy and permitting landscape), build new meaningful scientific relationships, and provide opportunities for cultural exchange. We expect that the connections made in 2019 will continue to strengthen and lead to valuable scientific collaborations, funding, publications, and advances in our understanding of biodiversity and its conservation for years to come.
